N-formylation of amines with carbon dioxide (CO2) and phenylsilane represents a sustainable and efficient pathway for synthesizing nitrogen-containing compounds, leveraging the growing interest in using CO2 as a feedstock in organic synthesis. Based on a bimetallic MOFs templating approach, this study synthesized an efficient NiCo alloy catalyst (termed as NiCo/CN-hmta) for the N-formylation reaction of phenylsilane, CO2, and N-methylbenzene amine. The catalytic performance results indicate that the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity in the N-formylation reaction process. Various characterizations and comparative experiments to explore the reasons for the enhancement in performance of NiCo/CN-hmta for N-formylation reaction. Additionally, there remain many speculative reaction pathways during the N-formylation reaction, and there is significant controversy regarding the order of interactions among phenylsilane, CO2, and N-methylbenzene amine. Therefore, this study aims to determine the reaction pathway of the MOFs-derived NiCo alloy catalyst in the N-formylation reaction through deuterated experiments, In-situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) and 13C NMR tests to capture intermediates during the reaction process. We hope that our research can provide some insights for future applications of alloy catalysts in N-formylation reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MOFs templated method NiCo alloy catalysts N-formylation reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The utilization of CO2 in chemical transformations has garnered increasing attention due to its role as the primary cause of the greenhouse effect. The current use of CO2 as a raw material for the production of chemical products has become a research hotspot, offering significant potential for environmental protection and sustainable development [1–8]. Among a range of CO2 catalytic conversion processes, the N-formylation of CO2 with aniline to produce formamides is a particularly significant reaction [4,9–18]. Because the formamides, a significant group of fine chemicals, serve as solvents (e.g., N,N-dimethylformamide) and as building blocks for organic syntheses. Among various amine N-formylation reactions, using hydrosilane for the N-formylation of amines is often preferred to avoid the use of flammable high-pressure H2 for safety reasons. Importantly, N-formylation reactions with CO2 and silane are typically more thermodynamically favorable and occur under milder conditions due to the polar and weaker nature of the Si-H bond compared to the HH bond in H2 [9,15,16,19–27]. In the field of heterogeneous catalysis (e.g. N-formylation reactions), metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based catalysts have gained significant interest in recent years due to their unique structures and tunable catalytic properties. These catalysts are derived from MOFs, which are crystalline materials composed of metal ions or clusters connected by organic linkers. By carefully selecting and manipulating the components of MOFs, it is possible to create catalysts with specific active sites and reactivity, making them versatile tools for various catalytic reactions. The high surface area and porosity of MOFs also contribute to their catalytic efficiency [28–51]. Overall, MOFs derived catalysts have shown promising potential for a wide range of catalytic applications in industries. To elucidate the mechanism of the N-formylation reaction, it is crucial to understand the step-by-step process by which a methyl group is transferred onto a nitrogen atom in a molecule. In general, the N-formylation reaction involves the use of a methylating agent, such as methyl iodide or methyl bromide, to introduce a methyl group onto the nitrogen atom. The reaction typically takes place under basic conditions, where the basic environment facilitates the electrophilic substitution mechanism. During the reaction, the nucleophilic attack of the nitrogen atom on the methylating agent occurs, leading to the formation of the N-methylated product. However, it is important to note that the N-formylation reaction may involve various competing pathways and side reactions, such as intra-molecular reactions or the generation of unwanted by-products [16,26]. Therefore, a comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanism of N-formylation is essential for optimizing reaction conditions, improving the yield, and minimizing the formation of by-products. Therefore, as shown in scheme 1 , a bimetallic NiCo-hmta MOF was synthesized using hexamethylenetetramine (hmta) as an organic linker, and nickel nitrate hexahydrate and cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate as metal sources by using a one-pot self-assembly method. Furthermore, a carbon-nitrogen supported NiCo alloy catalyst (NiCo/CN-hmta) was synthesized by pyrolysis in an argon atmosphere. Subsequently, the developed NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst was employed in the N-formylation reaction utilizing CO2 and phenylsilane. Various characterization techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy energy dispersive spectroscopy (HAADF-STEM-EDS), in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), and deuterium labeling experiments, were employed to elucidate the origin of the enhanced performance of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst in the N-formylation of amines with carbon dioxide. The catalytic tests demonstrated that the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst achieved a yield of 90 % for the N-formylation of amines with CO2 and maintained consistent performance over eight recycling cycles without any decrease in yield. 2 Experimental section The experimental details are provided in the Supplementary Information (SI) section including as Chemical reagents, synthetic procedures of as-prepared catalysts. 3 Results and discussion As shown in Fig. 1a-1b , the SEM was first used to observe the microstructure of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst. The SEM images reveal that the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst exhibits a block-like structure, and upon further magnification, its surface is found to be rough and exhibits a sponge-like structure [5,42,45]. This characteristic enhances the specific surface area and facilitates the formation of closely interconnected meso‑ and macroporous structures within the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, a finding that will be further validated through subsequent BET characterization. Additionally, this structure is beneficial for enhancing the mass transfer capabilities of the catalyst during the reaction process, thereby improving its catalytic activity [5,42,45]. Furthermore, we employed TEM to characterize the microstructure of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst. As shown in Fig. 1c, the active components in the bimetallic MOFs derived catalyst do not show significant sintering, indicating that the MOFs template method has somewhat improved the dispersion of the components within the catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 1d, the lattice fringe spacing measures 0.204 nm, which can be attributed to the crystal plane of the NiCo alloy [40,52–54]. Subsequent XRD analysis will be conducted to confirm the active components of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 2 a, the metal diffraction peak of the active component in the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst is positioned between the diffraction peaks of metallic Ni and metallic Co. This observation strongly suggests that the active components in the catalyst exist as a NiCo alloy. This alloy structure may significantly influence the catalytic performance, as the alloying of Ni and Co can alter their electronic structure, surface properties, and the interaction capabilities with reactants, thereby enhancing the efficiency and selectivity of catalytic reactions. To further verify the SEM characterization results mentioned above, the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) experiments on the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst was conducted. As shown in Fig. 2b, the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst displays a type II isotherm with a large specific surface area of 243.2 m2·g−1. This large specific surface area promotes the dispersion of active components on the catalyst's surface and facilitates mass transfer of reactants within the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, thereby improving the contact between the reactants and the active components of the catalyst, ultimately enhancing catalytic performance. From the BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) analysis of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, it can be seen that the pore structure size is mainly concentrated around 10 nm. This range of pore size is crucial for N-formylation reaction process. Because the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst with pore size of 10 nm can typically accommodate small molecular reactants effectively, allowing them to smoothly enter the active sites of the catalyst. Additionally, this pore size can balance the diffusion rate of the reactants with the rate of the catalytic reaction. In Raman spectroscopy characterization, the I D/I G ratio is commonly used to evaluate the defect level and crystallinity of carbon materials [55–58]. I D represents the intensity of the D band (∼ 1350 cm−1), which is typically associated with defects and imperfections in the structure, while I G denotes the intensity of the G band (∼ 1570 cm−1), which is related to the material's structural quality and graphite degree [59]. As shown in the Fig. 2d, the I D/I G ratio of the catalyst is 1.1, indicating a certain degree of defects in the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst. These defects and disorder have a promoting effect on the catalyst's performance in N-formylation, effectively enhancing the catalytic reaction activity. Moreover, the I D/I G ratio of 1.1 suggests a high level of graphitization in the catalyst, which is beneficial for improving electron transfer during the reaction, thereby enhancing the performance of NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst for N-formylation reaction. As depicted in Fig. 2e, the survey spectrum of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst indicates that its composition mainly includes Ni, Co, C and N elements, which is consistent with previous XRD analysis results. This consistency highlights the effectiveness of using multiple analytical techniques to confirm the composition of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst. By analyzing the high-resolution spectra of Ni 2p and Co 2p, we observe that the principal oxidation states of these two elements are at zero valence, suggesting they may exist in a metallic state within the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, which typically contributes to enhanced catalytic activity of NiCo/CN-hmta for N-formylation reaction. Moreover, when using NiCo-hmta MOFs derived catalysts, compared to Ni/Co-hmta derived catalysts (Fig. S1), the metal phase ratio and electronic states change primarily due to the synergistic effects between the two metals. The interaction between the bimetals leads to a redistribution of electrons. In monometallic Ni/Co-hmta MOFs, the electron cloud distribution of metal atoms is primarily influenced by their own atomic structure and surrounding ligands. In NiCo-hmta MOFs, however, there is an electron transfer between Ni and Co atoms. For example, due to the difference in electronegativity between Ni and Co (with Ni having an electronegativity of 1.91 and Co 1.88, respectively), electrons partially transfer from the relatively less electronegative Co atom to the Ni atom. This increases the electron cloud density around Ni atoms while decreasing it around Co atoms. Such changes in electronic states affect the catalyst's ability to adsorb reactants. Variations in electronic states may alter the activation energy of catalytic reactions [3,43]. Additionally, the high-resolution spectrum of N 1 s indicates a high content of pyrrolic N in the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst. Existing research suggests that pyrrolic N is beneficial for increasing the participation of aromatic compounds in reactions. This finding provides important evidence for optimizing catalyst design, indicating that the nitrogen-based components in the catalyst may play a positive role in catalytic reactions, improving its catalytic performance. As depicted in Fig. 3 , according to the HADDF-STEM image, the Ni and Co elements are confined within the carbon and nitrogen matrix, which helps to enhance the stability of the catalyst during the reaction process. The mapping images of Ni and Co elements indicate that they are well-dispersed in the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst without exhibiting aggregation, suggesting that the MOFs-templated method can effectively improve the dispersion of active components in their derived catalyst. EDS analysis data show that the content of Ni in the catalyst is 12.11 wt% and the content of Co is 11.07 wt%. This result is similar to that obtained from bulk phase analysis, indicating that the catalyst prepared by the MOFs templated method has a high degree of consistency between its surface and bulk phases. The N-formylation reaction is an important organic chemical reaction primarily used to convert amine compounds into the corresponding N-formamides [60–62]. Based on the characteristics of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, the N-formylation reaction was selected as a model reaction to assess its catalytic performance. From the Fig. 4 , it can be observed that the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst exhibits effective catalytic performance in the N-formylation reaction. Additionally, we know that the conditions of the catalytic reaction play a crucial role in the performance of the catalyst and the effectiveness of the reaction. For example, the reaction temperature significantly affects the reaction rate and selectivity. By adjusting the reaction temperature, we can find a balance that maximizes the activity of prepared catalysts while minimizing the occurrence of side reactions. Reaction time is also one of the important factors influencing product yield. By sampling at regular intervals, we can monitor the progress of the reaction, avoiding excessive reactions that may lead to product degradation and thus optimizing the time conditions. Furthermore, the amount of NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst needs to be matched with the scale of the reaction. Increasing the catalyst amount appropriately can enhance the reaction efficiency, but it is also necessary to consider the costs of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst and waste management. Selecting an appropriate solvent is crucial for the selectivity and yield of the reaction. The properties of different solvents, such as polarity and boiling point, can affect the reactivity and selectivity in the reaction. To further enhance the selectivity of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst in the N-formylation reaction and improve the product yield, we conducted systematic optimization of the reaction conditions for the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst for N-formylation reaction. This optimization not only helps improve the efficiency of the reaction but also protects the activity and stability of the N-formylation reaction catalyst under various reaction conditions. Specifically, we considered multiple factors, including reaction temperature, reaction time, substrate concentration, catalyst amount, and reaction medium. From the catalytic results, it can be seen that the catalyst, base, and PhSiH3 are indispensable elements for the entire reaction; none of them can be omitted. The reaction can only proceed smoothly when all three components are present simultaneously. Additionally, comparative experiments were conducted to evaluate the performance of Ni/CN-hmta, Co/CN-hmta, and NiCo/CN-hmta catalysts in the N-formylation reaction. As shown in Fig. S2, the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst demonstrated superior performance compared to the Ni/CN-hmta and Co/CN-hmta catalysts. In addition, the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyswith a TOF of 1.77 h⁻¹, which higher than those of Ni/CN-hmta (0.88 h⁻¹) and Co/CN-hmta (0.71 h⁻¹) catalysts This indicates that the bimetallic NiCo-hmta derived catalyst enhances performance during the N-formylation reaction process. Base was also important in this N-formylation reaction. Bases deprotonate N-methyl aniline to generate a nucleophilic amino anion, facilitating the reaction. They also neutralize acidic species produced during the reaction, maintaining an alkaline environment that favors the formation of N-formylation products and stabilizing active species to prevent side reactions. This study shows that cesium carbonate (Cs2CO3) has significant advantages over potassium carbonate (K2CO3) and triethylamine (Et3 N) in the N-formylation of N-methylaniline with CO2 and phenylsilane. Its stronger basicity efficiently deprotonates N-methylaniline, yielding a more nucleophilic amino anion, which enhances reaction rate and efficiency, especially for less reactive substrates. Cs2CO3 also demonstrates good solubility in water and various organic solvents, improving dispersion and enhancing reaction uniformity and rate. Overall, Cs2CO3 exhibits superior catalytic effects in the N-formylation reaction. Moreover, in the absence of a base, the reaction did not proceed. We also tested other polysubstituted silanes, such as diphenylsilane and triethoxysilane, in the N-formylation reaction; however, steric hindrance and the reactivity of the Si–H bond inhibited the reaction. Through combinatorial experiments conducted under these conditions, we identified the optimal reaction parameters. The optimal conditions are outlined below: Under the condition that the amounts of reactants is 0.5 mmol, the dosage of catalyst is 50 mg, the dosage of Cs2CO3 is 2 mol%, the reaction pressure of CO2 is 1 atm, and the reaction time is 6 h (all reactions were conducted under room temperature conditions). 3.3 Investigation on the reaction mechanism To determine the source of hydrogen in the N-formylation reaction catalyzed by the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, deuterated NMR experiments were conducted. From the experimental results (Fig. 5 ), using deuterated N-methylaniline under these optimized conditions did not result in deuterated aldehyde formation. However, when PhSiD3 was employed in the N-formylation reaction, the aldehyde was deuterated and the proportion of hydrogen atom and deuterium atom was 0.02:0.98, and the deuterium incorporation level of this aldehyde hydrogen was 98 %. These results suggest that the hydrogen in the aldehyde originated from phenylsilane. Currently, many reaction pathways in the N-formylation process remain speculative, and there is considerable debate regarding the sequence of interactions among phenylsilane, CO2, and N-methyl aniline. The main reason for this is the differing choices of catalyst types. To date, there have been no reports on the mechanisms of alloy catalysts in the N-formylation reaction. Therefore, this study aims to determine the reaction pathways of MOFs derived alloy catalysts in the N-formylation reaction by employing In-situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) and 13C NMR test to capture intermediates during the reaction process. The in-situ DRIFTS was firstly conducted to investigate the formation of intermediates during the N-formylation reaction catalyzed by the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the in-situ DRIFTS exhibits peaks corresponding to the CH bending vibration peak (δ C H, 701.1 and 750 cm−1, respectively), attributed to N-methylaniline [63]. Furthermore, from the enlarged section (Fig. 6b), it can be observed that with the increase of reaction time, the CH bending vibration peaks gradually exhibit a blue shift. This phenomenon is primarily due to the interaction between N-methylaniline and phenylsilyl formate (confirmed by 13C NMR, Fig. 7 a). As shown in Fig. 6a, in the infrared spectral region of 800–1000 cm−1, the stretching vibration peaks correspond to the Si-H stretching vibration peaks (∼ 921 cm−1) in phenylsilane and the Si-O-C stretching vibration peaks (∼ 850 cm−1) in the generated intermediates (phenylsilyl formate) [63]. From the enlarged section, it is evident that the changes in the Si-H stretching vibration peak of phenylsilane and the Si-O-C stretching vibration peaks of the phenylsilyl formate intermediate is significant. With the extension of reaction time, the intensity of the Si-H stretching vibration peaks in phenylsilane gradually decreases. The Si-O-C stretching vibration peaks in the phenylsilyl formate intermediates begins to appear after 20 min and its intensity gradually increases with the prolongation of reaction time. This indicates that the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst can effectively catalyze the reaction between phenylsilane and CO2. Additionally, in the intermediates, the appearance time of the Si-O-C stretching vibration peak is significantly earlier than the blue shift time of the CH bending vibration peak in N-methylaniline. This suggests that phenylsilane first reacts with CO2 to form the phenylsilyl formate intermediate, which subsequently reacts with N-methylaniline. Moreover, the changes in the Si-O (1133 cm−1) and CO (1115 cm−1) stretching vibration peaks further confirm the aforementioned reaction process. As the reaction time increases, the Si-O stretching vibration peak gradually appears and its intensity increases, while the CO stretching vibration peak shows the opposite trend. It is noteworthy that the NiCo alloy could enhance the CO2 (∼1607 cm−1) adsorption and formation of carboxylate (COOH*, 1678 cm−1) and formic acid (HCOOH, 1555 cm−1) when increase the reaction time [64]. Based on the reported work, the COOH* species easily transforms into the HCOO* intermediate, thereby increasing the yield of the product [64]. Furthermore, from Fig. 6a and 6f, it is evident that the changes in CO2, as a reactant, throughout the reaction are also quite significant. Its stretching vibration peaks are located at 2233 and 2297 cm−1, attributed to gaseous CO2 [65]. This further confirms that the reaction between phenylsilane and CO2 occurs prior to that with N-methylbenzenamine. In addition, the full width at half maxima (FWHM) of the Si-H stretching vibration in phenylsilane (2069 cm−1) gradually broadens with the extension of reaction time. This indicates that as the reaction time increases, the interaction between phenylsilane and CO2 strengthens. In the reaction of phenylsilane, CO2, and N-methyl aniline, if phenylsilane reacts preferentially with CO2, it will definitely generate a phenylsilyl formate intermediate. Therefore, we performed column chromatography to separate the intermediate product from the reaction and conducted 13C NMR analysis on the obtained product samples. As depicted in Fig. 7a, the reaction of PhSiH3 with CO2 in CD3CN resulted in the formation of the phenylsilyl formate intermediate, which was observed via 13C NMR directly at a chemical shift of 165.9 ppm [27]. Based on deuterium-labeling experiments, in-situ DRIFTS, and 13C NMR analyses, we proposed a comprehensive reaction mechanism for the N-formylation reaction involving phenylsilane, CO2, and N-methyl aniline, catalyzed by the alloy catalyst NiCo/CN-hmta (Fig. 7b). This N-formylation process can be divided into two main steps: the initial reaction of phenylsilane with CO2, followed by the subsequent reaction of the formed intermediate with N-methylaniline. In the presence of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, the silicon (Si) atom in phenylsilane is activated at the NiCo alloy sites, which serve as catalytic active centers. This activation facilitates a subsequent reaction where the activated Si atom interacts with CO2 through the process of insertion into the Si-H bond. This interaction results in the formation of a phenylsilyl formate intermediate, which is crucial for the progress of the reaction. Simultaneously, N-methylaniline undergoes a reaction with a base, leading to the generation of an ammonium salt. This ammonium salt plays an essential role in the catalytic process. In the presence of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, the ammonium salt then engages in a reaction with the previously formed phenylsilyl formate intermediate. This interaction yields N-methyl-N-phenylformamide and phenylsilanol as the final products, effectively completing the catalytic cycle. The mechanistic insights gained from our experiments elucidate the pivotal roles of the catalyst and the intermediate species, ultimately enhancing our understanding of this important reaction pathway in organic synthesis. Under optimized conditions, a series of N-methylaniline derivatives were tested to demonstrate the substrate suitability. As depicted in Table 1 , N-methylanilines with aryl halides in the para-position were transformed into the corresponding N-methyl-N-phenylformamide products with excellent yields (80–88 %, 3b-3d). Furthermore, no dehalogenated by-products were formed under these optimized conditions. For N-methyl-N-(4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)formamide, the yield was 85 % (3e). Unsaturated bonds, including -CN, ketone, and ester functionalities, were also tolerated in this CO2 system, yielding 77–85 % (3f-3 h). Electron-donating groups in the para-position resulted in yields of about 80–81 % (3i-3j). Similarly, electron-donating or -withdrawing groups in the meta position maintained high yields (85–90 %, 3k-3 m). Other N-substituted anilines such as alkyl, allyl, and ester derivatives yielded between 78 % and 90 % (3n-3r). Cyclohexylamine derivatives also showed tolerance with yields of 86–88 % (3s-3t). Heterocyclic N-methylaniline derivatives yielded approximately 75–77 % (3u-3v). From an environmentally friendly perspective, enhancing the cycling ability of catalysts helps to reduce resource consumption and environmental pollution, aligning with the goals of sustainable development [66]. Therefore, the assessment and optimization of cycling ability is an important aspect that should not be overlooked in the research and development of catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 a, due to the strong magnetism of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst, rapid separation can be achieved using a magnet, a method that not only significantly reduces costs but also markedly improves separation efficiency. By utilizing magnetic catalysts, it is possible to quickly separate the catalyst from the reaction products through simple magnetic force once the reaction is complete, thus avoiding the complex steps and potential losses associated with traditional separation processes. Based on the analysis of the cycling performance of NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst for N-formylation reactions, the study shows that NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst exhibits good catalytic cycling ability in the N-formylation reaction. After eight cycles, its catalytic performance shows no significant decline (Fig. 8b). This result indicates that the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst prepared using the MOFs-templated method can serve as an efficient NiCo catalyst suitable for N-formylation reactions. Furthermore, the XRD characterization was performed to investigate the structural stability of the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst during the N-formylation reaction (Fig. S3). Analysis of the XRD patterns for both fresh and spent NiCo/CN-hmta catalysts reveals that the diffraction peaks of NiCo alloy exhibited no significant changes throughout the entire reaction process. This not only demonstrates its good stability and reusability during the catalytic process but also provides important evidence for further optimizing catalyst design, thereby promoting the development of green chemistry and sustainable chemistry applications. 4 Conclusions A bimetallic NiCo-hmta MOFs was synthesized using hexamethylenetetramine (hmta) as the organic linker, along with nickel nitrate hexahydrate and cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate as metal sources through a one-pot self-assembly method. Additionally, a carbon-nitrogen supported NiCo alloy catalyst (NiCo/CN-hmta) was produced via pyrolysis in an argon atmosphere. The resulting NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst was subsequently utilized in the N-formylation reaction employing N-methylbenzene amine, CO2 and phenylsilane as reactants. The NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst exhibited high catalytic performance in the N-formylation reaction, primarily due to the NiCo alloy effect, a large specific surface area (243.2 m2·g−1), a small pore size distribution (∼10 nm), and a significant number of structural defects. Additionally, we employed deuterated NMR experiments, in-situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS), and 13C NMR tests to investigate the reaction mechanism of the NiCo/CN-hmta alloy catalyst in the N-formylation reaction. The generated COOH* and HCOO* intermediates are essential for improving overall N-formylation performance. These experiments provided strong evidence for the reaction pathway of the alloy catalysts in the N-formylation reaction, offering valuable insights for the subsequent application of supported catalysts in N-formylation reactions. coredata.dc:description: N-formylation of amines with carbon dioxide (CO2) and phenylsilane represents a sustainable and efficient pathway for synthesizing nitrogen-containing compounds, leveraging the growing interest in using CO2 as a feedstock in organic synthesis. Based on a bimetallic MOFs templating approach, this study synthesized an efficient NiCo alloy catalyst (termed as NiCo/CN-hmta) for the N-formylation reaction of phenylsilane, CO2, and N-methylbenzene amine. The catalytic performance results indicate that the NiCo/CN-hmta catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity in the N-formylation reaction process. Various characterizations and comparative experiments to explore the reasons for the enhancement in performance of NiCo/CN-hmta for N-formylation reaction. Additionally, there remain many speculative reaction pathways during the N-formylation reaction, and there is significant controversy regarding the order of interactions among phenylsilane, CO2, and N-methylbenzene amine. Therefore, this study aims to determine the reaction pathway of the MOFs-derived NiCo alloy catalyst in the N-formylation reaction through deuterated experiments, In-situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) and 13C NMR tests to capture intermediates during the reaction process. We hope that our research can provide some insights for future applications of alloy catalysts in N-formylation reactions.

coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient NiCo alloy catalyst fabricated by MOFs-templated strategy for N-formylation reaction of amines with CO2 and phenylsilane
